thread.section_title: Business News, Economy, Finance & ASX Market News
thread.title: RBA boost puts Australian dollar on track for best month since April
thread.title_full: RBA boost puts Australian dollar on track for best month since April

title: RBA boost puts Australian dollar on track for best month since April
text:
The Australian dollar rose on positive language from the RBA's minutes Photo: Bloomberg
The Australian dollar moved higher on Tuesday, putting it on track for its best month of gains since April, as the Reserve Bank of Australia minutes revealed optimism about the economy .
At 1pm AEST, the dollar was buying US73.76¢, slightly lower than its overnight high of US73.88¢.
"The currency is taking its cue from the RBA being a little bit more optimistic about the economy," Commonwealth Bank of Australia senior currency strategist Joseph Capurso said.
"For example, the labour market – business are hiring more people; they also talked about non-mining business profits increasing and business conditions are clearly above average," he said.
Advertisement The Australian dollar has now risen 1 per cent this month, despite falling to a six-year low after China moved to devalue its currency by almost 2 per cent against the US dollar.
That puts the currency's monthly performance ahead of all other major currencies excluding the Swedish krona.
The Aussie rallied from its morning low of US73.65¢ after the late morning release of the central bank's August board meeting minutes, which reiterated its gentler tone on the currency.
RBA governor Glenn Stevens said in the August statement accompanying the decision to hold the bank's official cash rate target steady at 2 per cent that the Australian dollar was adjusting to the significant decline in commodity prices, a turnaround from the previous month's language where it said "further depreciation" was needed.
National Australia Bank senior currency strategist Emma Lawson said improving Chinese property data, which reported a 0.3 per cent rise month on month in July, also provided a boost.
On an annual basis, Chinese new house prices fell 3.7 per cent, but improved on June's 4.9 per cent drop, raising hopes that the sluggish property sector had reached a bottom.
Meanwhile China left the midpoint rate from which its currency can trade almost unchanged, from 6.3969 yuan to the US dollar, to 6.3966. This is the second straight day the rate was left largely unchanged.
Mr Capurso said the yuan was becoming a "fading issue" for the Australian dollar.
"People are barely noticing it anymore, after a few days of excitement last week," he said.
Ms Lawson said traders were watching emerging markets which had come under enormous pressure from the yuan devaluation. But for the major currencies, the yuan had gone to the backburner.
"After the initial adjustment, this is fairly typical, in the first couple of days the markets are grappling with the new rules, as its not clear how it is going to work," she said.
"But it has become more market oriented and they get used to it, it goes to the backburner and we go back to watching potential policy moves and the economic [data]," she said.
Ms Lawson said she expected trading to remain quiet ahead of the US Federal Reserve minutes, due to be released early Thursday morning Australian time, as foreign exchange traders looking for further hints of an interest rate rise in September.
